title: stop serving grtp.co over HTTP

profile.name: Gratipay
profile.about: Gratitude? Gratipay! The easiest way for your company to pay for open source.

vulnerability_information:
Target Domain: grtp.co

1 Issue Details: Service available on HTTP
As per the policy details under scope on HackerOne portal(https://hackerone.com/gratipay), the 'grtp.co'. should be available only on port 443 or HTTPS protocol. However grtp.co service is running on port 80 too (i.e., running on HTTP protocol even). As we know this can leak lot of information about your target customers.

Side effects:
URL1) https://github.com/gratipay/grtp.co/blob/master/README.md#examples

From the above URL1 page details: you are referring to URLs of grtp.co which targets to HTTP based URLs instead of HTTPS.
Example code taken from URL 1 mentioned above:
<script data-gratipay-username="rummik"
  data-gratipay-widget="button"
  src="//grtp.co/v1.js" async></script>


Solution: If we have HTTPS already, what ever the services we host on out web sites should points towards HTTPS URIs/URLs, but not to HTTP based URIs/URLs. This way we can achieve 100% encrypted communication & guaranty end user's safety. If not an attacker can learn that a about of user's activity happening on HTTP and can setup a fake DNS record to drive "grtp.co/v1.js" or "grtp.co/xxxx" kind of requests to malicious domain and can serve infected java script files making them fall as his/her pray.

2 Issue Details: Information Disclosure

Leaking lot of technical details during discussions with H1 researchers
Example: https://hackerone.com/reports/116352

The above issue # 1 was identified while reading the report. That is why I am submitting both issues under one report.

Solution: Keep the details as crispy as possible while sharing with H1 researchers. Social Engineering is another possibility where a malicious researcher can make you leak more info.

Example code taken from URL 1 mentioned above:

Solution: If we have HTTPS already, what ever the services we host on out web sites should points towards HTTPS URIs/URLs, but not to HTTP based URIs/URLs. This way we can achieve 100% encrypted communication & guaranty end user's safety. activities.message: @Gratipay : Team, any update on the probable gap reported ? thanks.

activities.message:
@secbughunter We are [an open company](http://inside.gratipay.com/big-picture/welcome), so leaking technical details is not something we are concerned about. If you find direct credentials or a clear and present vulnerability, please report, otherwise we are not concerned to share technical details.

As to whether or not to serve grtp.co on HTTP ... I don't remember why we decided to allow both, but I agree that nowadays it is best to serve only over HTTPS.
activities.markdown_message:
@secbughunter We are an open company, so leaking technical details is not something we are concerned about. If you find direct credentials or a clear and present vulnerability, please report, otherwise we are not concerned to share technical details.

As to whether or not to serve grtp.co on HTTP ... I don't remember why we decided to allow both, but I agree that nowadays it is best to serve only over HTTPS.

@whit537: thank you very much for looking into the report, Chad !!
Good to know about your open company status.

Just FYI: Yesterday I happened to check the same issue accidentally and found that the HTTP service is intact.

activities.message: Assigning theoretical severity, therefore a $1 per [our policy](https://hackerone.com/gratipay).
activities.markdown_message: Assigning theoretical severity, therefore a $1 per our policy.

activities.message:
@trabajoduro: No comments from my end on the time gap.

However, what I learned is, on platform like H1, participating companies do get lot of reports daily, that means: more reports more work.

I see that you recently started your journey with H1, wishing you all the best, we have lot more to catch !!

Cheers !!

> on platform like H1, participating companies do get lot of reports daily, that means: more reports more work.

Very true. :-)

We have 30+ reports in our queue right now, all mild or theoretical risks except for two we're still classifying. Our queue is listed at: https://github.com/gratipay/inside.gratipay.com/issues/538#issue-140466992.

activities.message:
Hi @secbughunter and @trabajoduro,

Sorry for the delay! The first issue is being investigated [here](https://github.com/gratipay/grtp.co/pull/147), if you want to add something or to contribute to the PR, you're welcome!

Regarding the second one (*"2 Issue Details: Information Disclosure"*), I just wanted to add that the nginx configuration file was/is publicly available ;-)
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @secbughunter and @trabajoduro,

Sorry for the delay! The first issue is being investigated here, if you want to add something or to contribute to the PR, you're welcome!

Regarding the second one ("2 Issue Details: Information Disclosure"), I just wanted to add that the nginx configuration file was/is publicly available ;-)

activities.message:
[This issue has been fixed today](https://github.com/gratipay/grtp.co/pull/147). All the non-HTTPS requests are now redirected to https://grtp.co. 

Thanks for making Gratipay a safer place!
activities.markdown_message:

Thanks for making Gratipay a safer place!
